header.title: Additional Explanation about the Matter of the Inversion of the Panim and the Making Order of the Kelim

central_thesis: This explanation clarifies the intricate mechanics of the inversion of the 'Panim de Kelim' (faces of the vessels) and the subsequent ordering of the 'Kelim' (vessels) within a 'Partzuf'. It posits that 'Kelim' acquire their definitive form and 'Panim' inversion only after the complete 'Histalkut Ohr Malchut' (withdrawal of the Light of Malchut) from them, a process dictated by the interplay of 'Aviut' (thickness of desire), 'Masach' (screen), and 'Koma' (stature of light) specific to each 'Kli'.

structure_content.summary: The author addresses the inherent confusion in understanding the 'Rav's words' regarding the inversion of 'Panim de Kelim' and the ordering of 'Kelim', despite their apparent clarity in 'Ohr Pnimi'. This complexity arises from needing to simultaneously grasp the 'Histalkut haOhr', 'Hizdakchut haMasach', the specific 'Panim de Kelim' inversion, and the individual structure of each 'Kli'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Formation of Kelim and Panim Inversion
structure_content.summary: Kelim are formed exclusively after the 'Histalkut Ohr Malchut' (withdrawal of the Light of Malchut) from them, as taught by the Rav. This withdrawal marks the moment when the 'Panim' (face) of the Kli turns downward, initiating the inversion process for each Kli.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Attribute of Kelim, Aviut, and Koma
structure_content.summary: Every Kli possesses a specific 'Behinat Aviut' (grade of thickness/desire to receive) that corresponds to its 'Komat Ohr' (stature of Light). A Kli is named after the highest 'Sefira' it receives. For instance, 'Kli de Keter' (vessel of Keter) contains 'Komat Yechida' (stature of Yechida light) and requires 'Aviut de Behina Dalet' (fourth grade of Aviut). The 'Masach' (screen) on this 'Aviut' dictates the light reception. Without the adequate 'Aviut', a 'Masach' cannot operate within the 'Kli'.

The text highlights the fundamental opposition between the 'Aviut' present in a 'Kli' (its desire to receive) and the 'Hitlabshut' (clothing) of the 'Ohr' (Light) within it. For example, 'Kli de Malchut' has 'Aviut de Behina Dalet' but cannot 'clothe' (receive) the 'Komat Yechida' because it lacks the 'Behinat Hitlabshut' of 'Kli Keter'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Distinguishing Kelim by Hamshacha and Hitlabshut
structure_content.summary: The distinction between different 'Kelim' lies in their respective 'Behinot' (grades) of 'Hamshacha' (drawing down/reception) and 'Hitlabshut'. 'Kli de Keter' possesses 'Behina Dalet de Hamshacha' and 'Behinat Keter de Hitlabshut', while 'Kli Malchut' has only 'Behina Dalet de Hamshacha' but lacks 'Behinat Keter de Hitlabshut'. Similarly, 'Kli de Hochma' has 'Behina Gimel de Hamshacha' and 'Behina Gimel de Hitlabshut', whereas 'Kli ZA' has only 'Behina Gimel de Hamshacha' but only 'Behina Aleph de Hitlabshut', fitting for 'Komat Ruach'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Sequential Kli Formation Through Ohr Withdrawal
structure_content.summary: The process of 'Kli' formation is sequential. When 'Ohr Yechida' departs from the 'Partzuf' due to the 'Masach de Behina Dalet' purifying, 'Malchut' rises to 'ZA', and 'Kli de Malchut' is formed because it became completely devoid of 'Ohr'. 'Kli de Keter' only forms once 'Ohr Malchut' also departs from it. Furthermore, a 'Kli' is only truly formed when it is entirely without its specific 'Ohr'. An example is given: when 'Ohr Malchut' departs 'ZA', 'Kli de ZA' turns its 'Panim' downward and becomes a 'Kli', even if 'Ohr ZA' has not fully departed, because 'Ohr Hochma' has now left 'Kli Hochma'. But 'Hochma' does not become a Kli yet, as 'Ohr Bina' is still present within 'Kli Hochma'.

After the complete 'Histalkut' of all 'Orot' (Lights) from the 'Partzuf', most 'Kelim' assume a state of 'Panim de Tachton in Achor de Elyon' (the face of a lower Kli is directed towards the back of a higher Kli). The exceptions are 'Kelim de Keter' and 'Hochma', which remain 'Panim be Panim' (face to face). This is because the 'Reshimo de Behina Dalet' disappears, causing 'Keter' to remain in 'Behina Gimel' below, directly opposite 'Hochma' (also 'Behina Gimel').

The measurements of 'Koma' (stature) that extend according to the 'Aviut' in the 'Masach' are precisely ordered according to the 'Hitlabshut' (clothing) of the 'Sefirot de Ohr Yashar' (Direct Light). 'Komat ZA', for instance, refers to the measure of 'Ohr' that 'Behina Gimel de Ohr Yashar' (named 'ZA') can receive, comprising 'Orot Ruach Nefesh'. Similarly, 'Komat Behina Bet' refers to the 'Hitlabshut' in 'Behina Bet de Ohr Yashar', and 'Komat Hochma' to the 'Hitlabshut' of 'Hochma de Ohr Yashar'.

key_concepts.definition: Spiritual vessels or receptacles that hold and transmit divine light, formed through a process of contraction and withdrawal of light.

The 'face' or receptive aspect of a vessel. Its 'inversion' refers to a change in its orientation or spiritual disposition following the withdrawal of light, signifying its readiness to become a functional vessel.
The withdrawal or retraction of the divine light from the vessels. This is a fundamental concept in Lurianic Kabbalah, leading to the formation and rectification of 'Kelim'.
The purification or thinning of the 'Masach' (screen). As the screen loses its 'Aviut' (thickness/desire), it can no longer withstand the light, causing the light to withdraw.

Lit. 'thickness' or 'grossness'; in Kabbalah, it refers to the intensity of the desire to receive light, categorized into four 'Behinot' (grades): Dalet, Gimel, Bet, Aleph, and a root Behina Shoresh. Higher 'Aviut' signifies a greater desire to receive.

A spiritual screen or barrier at the end of the 'Kli' (vessel) that filters and limits the reception of 'Ohr' (light) based on the 'Aviut' (desire) of the Kli. It performs a 'Tzimtzum' (contraction) and 'Hizdakchut' (purification).
The 'stature' or spiritual level of light that a 'Kli' (vessel) is capable of receiving, determined by the strength of its 'Masach' (screen) and its 'Aviut' (desire).
The Light of 'Malchut', the lowest and most manifest 'Sefira'. Its complete withdrawal from a 'Kli' is specified as the trigger for the 'Kli's formation and the inversion of its 'Panim'.
A complete spiritual configuration or 'face', composed of a specific arrangement of 'Sefirot' operating as a unified whole, often likened to a person's spiritual stature.
The strongest and most complete grade of 'Aviut', representing the full desire to receive all light, associated with the 'Sefira' of 'Malchut'.
Lit. 'clothing'; the act of divine 'Ohr' (light) entering and dwelling within a 'Kli' (vessel), adapting itself to the vessel's capacity.
Lit. 'drawing down'; the ability or act of a 'Kli' (vessel) to draw down and receive 'Ohr' (light) from higher spiritual sources.

Lit. 'Direct Light'; the primordial, undifferentiated light descending directly from the spiritual source before its interactions with the 'Kelim' (vessels) and the processes of 'Tzimtzum' and 'Histalkut'.
Lit. 'face to face'; a state of complete alignment, direct connection, and harmonious reception between two spiritual entities or 'Partzufim'.

key_concepts.term: Panim de Tachton in Achor de Elyon
key_concepts.definition: Lit. 'the face of the lower (Kli) in the back of the higher (Kli)'; describes a specific orientation or relationship between vessels where a lower Kli's receptive aspect faces the less direct or 'back' aspect of a higher Kli, indicating a different mode of connection or influence.

practical_system.description: This text details a theoretical cosmological system rather than a direct practical magical system in the conventional occult sense. It describes the fundamental spiritual mechanics governing the creation of 'Kelim' (vessels) and their interaction with 'Orot' (lights) following the 'Tzimtzum' (contraction) and 'Histalkut haOhr' (withdrawal of light). While it does not outline specific rituals or spells, a deep understanding of these principles is inherently practical for advanced Kabbalistic work. The 'operative side' involves internalizing these processes to align one's consciousness and spiritual practice with the cosmic flow of emanation and rectification. The 'making order of the Kelim' is a cosmic process, and the practitioner's 'Avodat Hashem' (service of God) is to mirror and participate in this ordering through their intentions ('Kavanot') and actions, aiming to rectify the 'Kelim' within their own spiritual structure.
tools: Intellectual comprehension of Kabbalistic diagrams and texts
Concentration and visualization techniques in meditation
Ethical and spiritual conduct (Mitzvot) to refine one's own 'Kelim' and 'Aviut'.
rituals: Kabbalistic meditation (Hitbonenut) focusing on the interaction and ordering of Sefirot and Partzufim
Intentional prayer (Kavanah) aimed at aligning individual will with the cosmic process of Kelim rectification
Study and contemplation (Limmud) of these intricate Kabbalistic concepts as a form of spiritual work.

relevant_quotes.text: The making of the Kelim is done only after the Histalkut of the last Ohr from the Kli, as the Rav says in item 27. He says: 'Know, that all these Kelim did not gain Aviut and become Kelim only after the Histalkut of Ohr Malchut. At that time He turned His Panim from the Kli.'
You already know the attribute of the Kelim, that each and everyone must have a Behinat Aviut that is adequate to its Komat Ohr as the Kli is only named after the highest Sefira in its Koma.
You also know that the matter of the Aviut in the Kli and the matter of the Hitlabshut of the Ohr, are two opposites.

It follows, that the distinction between the Kli de Keter and the Kli de Malchut is in that the Kli de Keter has Behina Dalet de Hamshacha, as well as Behinat Keter de Hitlabshut. Conversely, the Kli Malchut has only Behina Dalet de Hamshacha, but is devoid of Behina Dalet de Hitlabshut, meaning Behinat Kli Keter.
It will make a Kli only after Ohr Malchut departs from the Kli de Keter too, as the Rav says above. Hence Malchut alone becomes a Kli since she is completely without Ohr.

It therefore follows, that after all the Orot have departed from the Partzuf, all the Kelim remained Panim de Tachton in Achor de Elyon, except the Kelim de Keter and Hochma, which remained Panim be Panim.

critical_analysis.relevance: This text is foundational for understanding the intricate mechanics of creation and rectification within Lurianic Kabbalah, particularly as interpreted by the Ashlag school. It is highly relevant for advanced students seeking to comprehend the nuanced processes of divine emanation, the formation of spiritual vessels ('Kelim'), and the dynamic interaction between light ('Ohr') and desire ('Aviut'). The precise delineation of 'Panim' inversion and 'Kli' ordering provides a crucial framework for appreciating the cosmic structure and the spiritual journey of 'Tikkun' (rectification). Without a firm grasp of these principles, deeper Kabbalistic texts and practices remain obscure.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for this text consists of advanced students, scholars, and practitioners deeply immersed in the study of Lurianic Kabbalah, specifically those familiar with the terminology and conceptual framework of the Ashlag method. It assumes prior knowledge of basic Kabbalistic concepts, 'Sefirot', 'Partzufim', and the general principles outlined in 'Ohr Pnimi'. This is not an introductory text and would be unintelligible to beginners in Western Esotericism or general occult studies without significant preparatory learning in Kabbalah.
